summary.seg: This composite manuscript is comprised of four parts, each originally belonging to separate medieval books, but which were all bound together by the time the manuscript was given to Clare College. The manuscript was given at an unknown date by John Heaver John Heaver (d. 23 June 1670) (d. 1670) who had been a student at the College and in later life was a Fellow of Eton College Eton College and a Canon of St George's Chapel, Windsor St George's Chapel, Windsor .

Part 1 of this manuscript is comprised of eight leaves now bound apart with four leaves at the beginning of the volume (ff. 1-4) and four leaves at the end (ff. 230-232, 234); the leaves contain part of a poem in medieval French about the death of Thomas Becket ( Thomas Becket Thomas Becket (?1118-1170) copied in the 13th century.

Part 2 is the oldest and largest part of the composite. Part 2 contains a selection of popular medical texts in Latin and was probably copied in Italy in the late 12th or early 13th centuries. The start of each major text in this section is accompanied by a beautiful decorative initial, see e.g., ff. 63r and 104v and there are also pen-flourished initials and small marginal creatures and grotesques in several places, see, e.g., f. 101v for a combination of these motifs. The final few leaves of Part 2 (ff. 125v-130v) contain a group of medical and culinary recipes in Latin.

Part 3, like Part 2, is medical, but it contains a single text, Book 2 of De dietis uniuersalibus et particularibus by Isaac Iudaeus, now misbound with the final three quires in this part presented out of order. Part 3 was probably made in England in the 13th century.

Part 4, as with Parts 2 and 3 contains medical material in Latin, and includes popular medical treatises such as the Antidotarium nicholai, the curis mulierum attributed to 'Trota', and Hippocrates' De regimine acutorum. Part 4 was probably made in England in the second half of the 13th century.

It is not known when all four parts of the composite were joined together, although they were certainly in that form by the time of John Heaver's donation, as his partially erased donation inscription is present on f. 1r. While the Thomas Becket poem is rather plainly executed, all of the other parts exhibit a relatively high degree of decoration for the genre and the decorative initals in Part 2 are particularly fine, so it seems that this composite was assembled by someone with an eye for aesthetic choices as well as an interest in medicine.

Dr Sarah Gilbert
Project Cataloguer, Curious Cures Project
Cambridge University Library

p.secFol: et parum nutrit . et ad digerendum etiam durum (132r).

foliation.note: Foliated in the upper outer corner of each recto in ink in Hindu-Arabic numerals. Several mistakes in the foliation sequence; many folio numbers are skipped or duplicated.
Designations for the paper endleaves, ff. [i]-[ii] and [iii]-[iv] enclosed in [square brackets] were assigned in 2022 by the Curious Cures Project for use in this online record.
Folio 85 an inserted slip of parchment; counted in the total number of leaves in Extent.
Folio 25 had been numbered 27 in the original foliation, but was later cancelled and changed in pencil to '25'.
Designations for the duplicate foliations, ff. 146, [146a], 221, [221a] enclosed in [square brackets] were assigned in 2022 by the Curious Cures Project for use in this online record.

collation.p:
A composite manuscript comprised mostly of quires of 8 leaves:
Quire 18-1 (1st missing; ff. 5-11)
Quire 28 (ff. 12-19)
Quire 38 (misfoliated and miscorrected; ff. 20-30)
Quires 4-78 (ff. 31-62)
Quires 8-98 (ff. 63-78)
Quire 108+1 (a slip inserted after the 6th leaf; ff. 79-87)
Quires 11-128 (ff. 88-103)
Quire 136+1 (7th leaf inserted; misfoliated, f. 110 skipped; ff. 104-111)
Quires 14-158 (ff. 112-127)
Quire 16three (perhaps originally a quire of four with the last leaf excised, probably blank; ff. 128-130) |
Quire 174 (misfoliated, f. 133 skipped; ff. 131-135)
Quire 188 (ff. 136-143)
Quire 198 (misfoliated, f. 146 duplicated; ff. 144-146 [146a]-150)
Quire 208 (ff. 151-158
Quire 2110 (ff. 159-168
Quire 228 (ff. 169-176)|
Quire 238 (ff. 177-184)
Quire 248 (misfoliated, foliation skips from f. 190 to f. 200; ff. 185-201)
Quires 25-268 (ff. 202-217)
Quire 278 (misfoliated, f. 221 duplicated; ff. 218-221 [221a]-224)
Quire 286-1 (6th excised, perhaps blank or former pastedown; ff. 225-229) |
collation.formula: 18-1 (1st missing) 28 38 4-78 8-98 108+1 (a slip inserted after the 6th leaf) 11-128 136+1 (7th leaf inserted) 14-158 16three | 174 188 198 208 2110 228| 238 248 25-268 278 286-1 (6th excised)

signatures.p: Quire designations in the lower outer corner of the first recto of each quire in pencil in Hindu-Arabic numerals.

binding.p: Late-17th century binding. Full bound in calf over millboard with matching decoration in blind to left and right covers. Covers are decorated with two concentric double-fillet frames, the outermost frame set at the perimeter of the board, the innermost frame inset from the outer by c. 25mm. A fleuron set at each corner of the inner frame pointing towards the nearest corner of the outer frame; fleuron is a stylised fleur-de-lys. Spine is capped at head and tail openings by the cover material folded over and inside the spine; no head or tail bands visible. Five raised bands and a half-band at the tail. Perimeter of each spine compartment decorated with a double fillet. Red morocco label applied to spine with the title TRACTATUS MEDICI tooled in gold.

Paper pastedowns set over the turn ins. Right pastedown is blank. The left pastedown contains:
Former shelfmark 'Kk.3.13' in ink, struck out
Ownership inscription in pencil 'Clare College James 12'
A Clare College shelfmark 'G'.3.2' in ballpoint pen
Rust stains on ff. 1r and 234v indicate the presence of a metal fastening in the centre of the fore edge of a previous binding.

history.acquisition: Given to Clare College by John Heaver John Heaver (b. ?1617, d. 1670) who was admitted as a sizar at Clare College 20 August 1635 matriculated in 1636, gained a B.A. in 1639-40, an M.A. in 1643, and a D.D. (Lit. Reg.) in 1661. Heaver also gave MSs 14, 18, 24, and 26 to Clare College. Heaver's ownership inscription can be found on f. 1r: Iohannes Heaver dono dedit. See also: Venn HVR635J.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on M. R. James, A descriptive catalogue of the Western manuscripts in the library of Clare College (Cambridge, 1905)

availability.p: Visitors to Clare College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Clare College Archives.

monogr.title: La Vie de Thomas Becket par Beneit
Women's healthcare in the medieval West: texts and contexts
Women's healthcare in the medieval West

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Clare College, MS 12, ff. 1-4 and 230-232 234

msItem.title: Vie de saint Thomas le martyr
msItem.author: Beneit le moine

msItem.title: Vie de saint Thomas le martyr
msItem.author: Beneit le moine
msItem.incipit:
1r For sul i tant il mesprist
Ke larceweske pas nelfist
Seint thomas
Kar cil ke la curune imist
msItem.explicit:
4v E de ses biens seum parcener
Et od li puissum regner
Finablement . Amen

msItem.title: Vie de saint Thomas le martyr
msItem.author: Beneit le moine
msItem.incipit:
230r A mer le deust e seruir
Des ke a la mort
msItem.explicit:
234v Seignors dist il si vos pleist
Quant mi sane espandre deit

msItem.note: Before their (re-)use as endleaves, ff. 1-4 and 230-234 once existed as a single quire of 8 leaves. In their present state the leaves are designated ff. 1, 2, 3, 4, 230, 231, 232, 234 (the designation 'f. 233' was skipped by the foliator in error as a leaf does not appear to have been lost), but these designations do not reflect the original sequence of the leaves. The leaves were originally arranged ff. 1, 2, 230, 231, 232, 234, 3, 4, i.e., the opening four leaves were once the two outer bifolia of the quire, and the closing four leaves were once the two inner bifolia of the quire.
Text is edited by B. Schlyter (Lund 1941); this manuscript has the designation 'C' in the edition. According to Schlyter's edition, Clare College MS 12 contains lines 1207-1824, 2095-2100, 2113-end

listBibl.bibl: B. Schlyter, 'La Vie de Thomas Becket par Beneit', Ãtudes Romanes de Lund IV (1941)

collation.p: Originally 1 quire of 8 leaves, now endleaves ff. 1-4 and 230-232, 234. The opening four leaves were once the two outer bifolia of the quire, and the closing four leaves were once the two inner bifolia of the quire.

supportDesc.condition: Leaves are in good condition. Small rust stains in the centre of the outer margins of the leaves caused by the metal fitting for a fastening on a former binding. Minor rat damage to the centre of the outer margin, but no damage to text.

layout.seg: Ruled in single-column format, frame and lines in both ink and leadpoint. 40 lines to page, written below top line. Formatted for verse, with a majuscule initial at the beginning of each line set slightly apart from the remainder of the word.

handNote.p: Written in a northern textualis formata of the 13th century.

additions.note: Ownership inscription Iohannes Heaver Dono dedit in the outer margin of f. 1r in ink in a late 17th century hand, the last two words struck out.
A former Clare College shelfmark Kk-4-8 Aul: Clare in the outer margin of f. 1r in ink, in a late 17th century hand.

msItem.title: De dietis uniuersalibus et particularibus
msItem.author: Isaac Iudaeus (Ishaq Ibn Suleiman)
msItem.incipit: 5r et perfeccio accionis eorum regineritium est
msItem.note: The text is defective at the opening and begins part of the way through De dietis uniuersalibus et particularibus, Lib. 1, Cap. 1, Lect 2 according to the numbering of the Lyon edition.
Printed with the commentary of Petrus Hispalensis in Omnia opera Ysaac (Lyon, 1515); note that Clare College MS 12 does not contain the commentary of Petrus Hispalensis.
M. R. James says that this text is 'no doubt in an Italian hand', but the hand in fact appears to be English or French.

msItem.title: Practica medicinae [Latin]
msItem.author: Bartholomaeus, Salernitanus
msItem.incipit: 63r PRACTICA diuiditur in duo scilicet in scienciam conseruatiuam sanitatis et curatiuam egritudinis
msItem.explicit: 103v Postea purgetur cum apozimate quod recipit

note.p: Slip of parchment (f. 85r) added with text (recto only) in a contemporary hand that supplies text missing on f. 84v: the scribe has added a signe-de-renvoi to the lacuna and at the start of the text on f. 85r.

Glosses in hands of ?16th century English appearance as follows:
88v outer margin 'the ravenynge evyll' glossing mania
89r outer margin 'the slommerynge evyll' glossing litargia
91v outer margin 'the pose' glossing Coriza
These glosses were all noticed by Professor Faith Wallis of McGill University and shared in a private communication.

msItem.title: Liber aureus [Latin]
msItem.author: Johannes Afflacius
msItem.incipit: 104v Si dolor capitis est uel fit
msItem.note: On f. 104r: List of capitulae (3 columns, lemma initial in alternating red or blue): De dolor capitis ... De ypostasibus urinarum

collation.p:
Quires of 8 leaves, the first leaf lost from the first quire. A slip of parchment (f. 85) inserted during the main copying stint to supply a lacuna in the text on f. 84v. Quire 13 is a quire of 6 leaves, with a singleton inserted at the end of the quire at the time the text was copied. Quire 16 was probably once a quire of 4 leaves; 3 leaves are extant, the 4th leaf presumably excised:
Quire 18-1 (1st missing; ff. 5-11)
Quire 28 (ff. 12-19)
Quire 38 (misfoliated and miscorrected; ff. 20-30)
Quires 4-78 (ff. 31-62)
Quires 8-98 (ff. 63-78)
Quire 108+1 (a slip inserted after the 6th leaf; ff. 79-87)
Quires 11-128 (ff. 88-103)
Quire 136+1 (7th leaf inserted; misfoliated, f. 110 skipped; ff. 104-111)
Quires 14-158 (ff. 112-127)
Quire 16three (perhaps originally a quire of four with the last leaf excised, probably blank; ff. 128-130)
collation.signatures: Medieval quire signatures I, II, III, IV, I in ink in the lower margins of the last versos of Quires 8-11 and 13.

catchwords.seg: Catchwords in the lower margins of Quires 8-11 and 13.

supportDesc.condition: Good condition. Minor rodent damage to centre of fore edge of each leaf. Minor textual losses to marginalia due to trimming. A portion of the lower margin of f. 6 cut away with no disruption to text.

layout.seg: Ruled in ink in single-column frame and lines. Typically 34 lines to the page and written above top line.

handNote.p: Written in a southern Textualis libraria of perhaps Italian origin by at least two scribes.

Marginal annotations by a scribe writing a 13th century northern Textualis currens of English appearance. The scribe of the marginal annotations also added punctuation and corrections to the main text.

decoNote.p:
Marginal illustrations as follows:
79r - a feline creature outlined in red and tinted with blue and anchored to an initial 'M' on the same page by a decorative tendril
80r - human faces incorporated into a spray border in the outer and lower margin extending from an initial 'Y' on the same page
80v - a naked human figure outlined in blue and holding their right knee in the outer margin and anchored to an initial 'A' (for 'arthetica', i.e., arthritic pain) on the same page by a decorative tendril
93vA dragon's head outlined in red with a decorative spray of red and blue flourishes emerging from its mouth into the lower margin and anchored to an initial 'S' on the same page by a decorative tendril
94v a man's head in profile outlined in red and anchored to an initial 'D' on the same page by a decorative tendril
96v - a ?feline creature outlined in red and tinted with ochre and green in the outer margin but enclosed within the matrix of an initial 'D' on the same page
100v - a bird outlined in red in the outer margin of the page, with beak open as if to peck a decorative flourish off an initial 'S'
101v - a dragon outlined in blue and incorporated into a decorative border in the outer and lower margin extending from an initial 'S' on the same page
Outline sketches of busts of a man and a woman in the lower margins of ff. 29v-30r. The male figure's hat and hairstyle are suggestive of late-15th or early 16th century fashions.

Inhabited initial on f. 104v, the main body of the initial painted with gold. Major decorative initial on f. 63r with use of gold and foliate motifs. A face outlined in red added to the counterspace of an initial 'O' (for 'Oculi patiuntur' i.e., a chapter on various eye problems) on f. 89r.

Flourished initials in red and blue at the major divisions of the text, with the most significant initials further embellished with flourishes extended along the inner and/or lower margin, e.g., ff. 9v, 47r, etc.
Plain initials in red or blue at the minor divisions of the text.
Rubricated headings (red only) at the divisions of the text.
Decorative line fillers in red at the end of some rubricated headings, e.g., f. 58v.

Guide letters for decorative initials visible in the left margin of some leavees; note that where guide letters are present in the left margin of a recto, the letter is almost always too deeply situated in the gutter to be visible in the photograhic images of this manuscript.

origin.origDate: Last quarter of the 12th century, or first half of the 13th century.

msItem.title: De dietis uniuersalibus et particularibus
msItem.author: Isaac Iudaeus (Ishaq Ibn Suleiman)
msItem.incipit: 131r Compleuimus in prio libro uniuersalem significationem
msItem.explicit: 176v quibus non castratis sunt meliores . omnes non decrepiti . in
msItem.note: Begins at De dietis uniuersalibus et particularibus, Lib. 2, Prologus. Final portion of text is at f. 168v (end of misbound Quire 21) De dietis uniuersalibus et particularibus, Lib. 2 ... eorum sunt nutribiliora . et in sanguinem conuertibiliora .
Catchwords indicate that the Quires in this Part are misbound: the correct order of the quires according to the catchwords is: 17, 18, 19, 22, 20, 21.
Printed in Omnia opera Ysaac (Lyon, 1515) in the version with the commentary of Petrus Hispalensis; Clare College MS 12 does not contain the Petrus Hispalensis commentary.

p.secFol: 132r et parum nutrit . et ad digerendum etiam durum

collation.p:
Quires of mostly 8 leaves (Quire 17 a quire of 4 leaves), now misbound. Catchwords indicate that the correct order of the quires should be Quires 17, 18, 19, 22, 20, 21.
Quire 174 (misfoliated, f. 133 skipped; ff. 131-135)
Quire 188 (ff. 136-143)
Quire 198 (misfoliated, f. 146 duplicated; ff. 144-146 [146a]-150)
Quire 208 (ff. 151-158
Quire 2110 (ff. 159-168
Quire 228 (ff. 169-176)

catchwords.seg: Catchwords in the lower margin of the last verso of Quires 17-20, and 22, no catchword in Quire 21. The catchwords in Quires 19, 20, and 22 indicate that the correct order of the quires in this sequence

supportDesc.condition: Good condition. Minor rodent damage to centre of fore edge of each leaf. Minor losses to marginalia and decoration due to trimming.

layout.seg: Ruled in ink, in single-column format, frame and lines. Written above top line, typically 35-36 lines to the page.

handNote.p: Written in an English textualis libraria.

decoNote.p: Flourished initials at the major and minor divisions of the text, either a red letter with blue flourishing or the reverse. Puzzle initial on 131r, with flourishes extended across the upper margin and the majority of the way down the inner margin.
Paraph marks in red or blue to separate minor sections of text.

msItem.title: Antidotarium Nicholai
msItem.author: Nicholas Salernitanus
msItem.incipit: 177v Ego nicolaus a quibusdam rogatus in practica medicine

msItem.title: De regimine acutorum [Latin]
msItem.author: Hippocrates
msItem.explicit: 221r et in hiis minus congruum est qui solo dicuntur potu sed conu
msItem.note: An early modern reader has added a title for the work 'Experimenta Atrote' in the upper margin of f. 213v. The early modern reader seems to have read this text De regimen acutorum (ff. 213v-221r) with the following text De curis mulierum (ff. 221v-227r) which ends with a final rubric Expliciunt Experimenta Atrote' and taken De regimen acutorum as the first part of De curis mulierum, and so they supplied a title to what they assumed to be the start of a single work.

msItem.title: De curis mulierum
msItem.rubric: 221v Incipit liber trote de curis mulierum
msItem.incipit: 221v Ut ait ypocras de curis mulierum compendiosa nobis traditio facit uiuendum est que tam superfuerit
msItem.note: This is the 'DCM 2' version of the text according to the classification system described by M. Green in 'The Development of the Trotula'.

This text is often attributed in medieval manuscripts and modern scholarship to Trota Trota , but see M. Green 'Development of the Trotula' for a discussion of why this attribution should be rejected.
Title added in the upper margin of f. 221v in a later hand.

listBibl.bibl: M. H. Green, âThe Development of the Trotulaâ, in Womenâs Healthcare in the Medieval West Texts and Contexts, ed. by M. H. Green (Aldershot: Ashgate, 2000), p. V:119-213, originally printed in Revue d'Histoire des Textes (1996)

Manuscript 11 in M. Green, âA Handlist of the Latin and Vernacular Manuscripts of the So-Called Trotula Texts. Part I: The Latin Manuscriptsâ, Scriptorium. Revue Internationale Des Ãtudes Relatives Aux Manuscrits, 50 (1996), 137â75

msItem.title: Compendium Salerni (extracts)
msItem.incipit: 228r Duplici me cogente causa socii dilectissimi
msItem.note: Text begins with a prologue (f. 228r), followed by a list of capitula (f. 228rv), before the text begins proper Medicina est sciencia apponendi on f. 228v.

listBibl.bibl: Renzi V, 201-32 (Supplanting III, 52-65), R. Creutz, Quellen V.iv (1936), pp. 9-37

support.material: Parchment (HFFH). Outer margin of f. 204r is a fold-out flap c. 25mm wide, and contains marginal annotations that strayed too far beyond the trimming boundary when the quire stack was being shaped for binding. Small parchment tab marker on f. 210rv; tab is part of an originally wider outer margin with the rest of the margin cut down around the tab.

collation.p:
Quires of mostly 8 leaves, the final quire of 6 with the 6th leaf excised (perhaps a blank or former pastedown).
Quire 238 (ff. 177-184)
Quire 248 (misfoliated, foliation skips from f. 190 to f. 200; ff. 185-201)
Quires 25-268 (ff. 202-217)
Quire 278 (misfoliated, f. 221 duplicated; ff. 218-221 [221a]-224)
Quire 286-1 (6th excised, perhaps blank or former pastedown; ff. 225-229)

supportDesc.condition: Good condition. Minor rodent damage to centre of fore edge of each leaf. Minor losses to marginalia and decoration due to trimming.

layout.seg: Ruled in ink, in single-column format, frame and lines. Written below top line, typically 32-33 lines to the page.

handNote.p: Written by several scribes writing an English textualis libraria.

decoNote.p: Flourished initials at the major and minor divisions of the text, either a red letter with blue flourishing or the reverse. No decoration after f. 215v.

change.persName: Dr Sarah Gilbert, Project Cataloguer, Curious Cures Project, Cambridge University Library
